description: The Distillery District is an internationally acclaimed village of brick-lined streets and dozens of vibrantly restored Victorian Industrial buildings. It’s one of Ontario’s hottest tourist attractions and home to live theatres, galleries, fashion, design and jewelry boutiques, unique cafes and award-winning restaurants. It’s all completely closed to traffic and just a few minutes walk from downtown Toronto.

reviews.title: Great area for walking, shopping and eating
text: A gorgeous area of Toronto to dine and shop and walk around!
Lots of great shops and the chocolate shop Soma is sooo good! Lots of art and if you have time the theatre is a great evening date night!

reviews.title: Worth a Visit
text: This is the old part of Toronto restored which has shops and restaurants.  I enjoyed this place, I stopped for ice coffee in a shop selling unique jams, spreads for sandwiches and other neat things.  It was so nice and relaxing!

reviews.title: Great atmosphere
text: Really enjoyed our trip to the distillery district. Liked walking around the quaint shops, brick lined lanes and stopped for a drink in the mill street brewery. I liked the vibe and the atmosphere. Would recommend a visit.

reviews.title: Good shops and restaurants in historic setting
text: The Distillery District is a 20-30 minute walk from Downtown Toronto. It was historically, as its name suggests, former distillery buildings. These have now been converted into a very pleasant attraction with a number of restaurants, bars and shops. If the weather is good, there are plenty of places to sit outside. This is a good location for buying gifts, for example jewelry, candles, etc.

reviews.title: Cool spot
text: What a unique & historic pit stop during our Toronto vacation! The Distillery district is an area of preserved historic buildings that are now shops, coffee shops, bars & places to eat! It was so beautiful to walk around & take in the historical beauty of the buildings while enjoying shopping. Very clean & easy to navigate! Easy street parking a couple blocks over & very easy to walk around. Some highlights of our Distillery visit includes Balazacs coffee shop, street vendors, reading about the buildings history & taking photos of the beautiful buildings! Loved the vibe here & was so happy we made time for this during our Toronto visit!

reviews.title: Win, win.
text: What a lovely historic area. A great mixture of individual shops, cafes and culture. Our first day in Toronto and we left impressed. Not too hot on the massive skyscrapers but this area was a win-win.

reviews.title: A Tourist Spot Made Only for Tourists
text: Large groups of Asian tourists were clearly enjoying the picturesque views. Their smartphone cameras were glowing within minutes. If you, like them, don’t mind that this place is a tourist trap with little depth, go ahead and make the trip.
We walked through the relatively small area in just a few minutes and hurried back downtown, where the vibe feels more authentic.

reviews.title: great industrial architecture
text: This district east of the city centre is characterised by industrial architecture from the 19th century. The area has been declared as a historic monument. Not surprising, as it is rare to see architecture from this period so well preserved in North America. There are imposing Victorian buildings, chicly converted warehouses, lofts with high ceilings and cobbled streets full of character.

reviews.title: Neighborhoods in Toronto
text: This shopping and entertainment area is built on the site of the old Godderham & Worts Distillery.  Apart from the  architectural significance, there is shopping, bars & coffee shops and it is one of the best Xmas Markets in the world.  It is within walking distance to the Port of Toronto and Marina with bicycle and walking trails and a ferry to Toronto Island Park.

reviews.title: Great Visiting Spot
text: Great place to go with your partner and just walk around the streets and get the feel for victorian style neighbourhood. Good place to take friends and out of town relatives. Lots of shopping and food options and they most often have events for weekends or holiday seasons.

reviews.title: Distillery in the daytime or nighttime??
text: I love walking around the Distillery and exploring different stores and cafes. This time I visited in the morning and noticed that it's less busy, which means you get a better chance to appreciate the architecture and explore the art galleries. At night, it's more lively and the atmosphere is magical, especially when the winter village goes live. I find that weekdays are the best time to visit if you want to avoid crowds.
I found this Distillery District map helpful

reviews.title: A wonderful indoor outdoor market and gallery
text: A great place to visit to eat, drink, theatre and shopping. Be careful if you are going when there are events as it is very busy and sometimes they charge an entry free later at night.

reviews.title: This represents the location, nothing more
text: We thought there might be some distilleries there. It was more of a tourist location for eateries and shops.   The entire history was on one placard on the West side of the location. 2 of the eateries were closed for private parties on a Monday afternoon.  We were disappointed by the lack of interesting things to see.

reviews.title: We’ll worth a visit
text: Vibrant, buzzy, a lovely place to visit.. especially on an early evening as it starts to wake up…great selection of bars and food places too

reviews.title: Very cute area!  Tad confusing at night to find specific places
text: We went there to have dinner at El Catrin and stopped for ice cream afterward at "Scooped".  I wish we would have been there earlier in the day to see the historic displays!  The ambiance is fantastic and there are many places to sit and enjoy.  It was within walking distance of our hotel and easy to get to, very safe.  I'll go back there when I return to Toronto.

reviews.title: Great chill out
text: Ome of my favourite places of The city.
A bit far away from downtown but easy access anyway. It's a great place to walk around, see the little shops and maybe have a drink or dine al fresco. There's so many choices.
Find the love sign and the peace sign.

reviews.title: Bustling
text: Bustling. There were many people visiting the place for the Christmas activities. Access via public transportation was easy, and there were a lot of activities and shops to enjoy.

reviews.title: Artsy Experience
text: We absolutely love the distillery historic district. When we went, they were having a French movie night. It was nice to walk around and visit the different shops and vendors. I highly recommend it.

reviews.title: Love the ambiance
text: The art around here is great.  The buildings were built in the 1830’s.  Parking was easy.  I got a coffee at Balzac’s. Safe. Clean area.

reviews.title: Underwhelming.
text: Mostly a hyped-up place. Really not as amazing as people made it seem like. Only visit it if you're in the area or know that there are specific events happening.

reviews.title: Superb complex
text: This is a superb complex in old Toronto. Lots of bars,cafes ,shops and art galleries. A great place to wander around and visit the numerous bars, especially the gin distillery.

reviews.title: Must-see!
text: This District is a must-see.
The tour is our best Toronoto Experience so far. We learned a lot about the history and bring all those nice little stories and funfacts back home.

reviews.title: Not What I Expected
text: I don't know if it was the time of day (evening) or time of year (April) but everything was closed and it felt very deserted. We were hoping to ramble around to a few places for bites and drinks  but this isn't really that kind of place. Luckily I'd picked a spot for dinner and they were open. Otherwise this feels like any other open air mall in a more historic setting. I'd skip it and head to Yorkville or Dundas and Ossington or one of the other truly bustling restaurant districts in the city.

reviews.title: Fun little spot
text: We had fun, more for adults, but Soma chocolates was quite a treat if you have younger ones. Lots of places to eat and have a drink.

reviews.title: Insta Friendly
text: If you’re wanting some pics for the gram then this is a good place to go.
A few installations to take pictures with (shown in pics attached).

For the time of year we went, there wasn’t much open and it was pretty deserted so can’t give this a proper review but from what we saw, it was fun and I expect this is bustling in the Summer but we went in the Winter time.
I’m still glad I went as there are still a few things to see.
I would say, the surrounding areas are pretty run down and isn’t the prettiest of areas to be in.

reviews.title: Great area to explore
text: The Distillery District is a great area to visit, both in the summer and winter. There is a lot to explore and the area itself is very nice. Lots of great photo ops.

reviews.title: Distillery district, cool place to visit
text: Interesting place to visit we visited in December so they had the Christmas market on , we visited during the day there were lots of stalls and shops to spend your time perusing. The Xmas decorations were a little different but the Dior Xmas tree looked fantastic.
I would like to visit the area without the Christmas market to get a better picture of the distillery district it seemed like a chilled area to visit.

reviews.title: Worth a visit when in Toronto
text: We visited while in Toronto in February. It was a long cold walk but worth it. Given the time of the year it was really quiet which was really nice and as we didn't have to fight the crowds.

We loved the red brick architecture and walking around the historic buildings. There is a great collection of shops and cafes and something for everyone. The prices were reasonable it was a really nice place to visit.

reviews.title: A nice distillery fistoric district
text: We liked this location, with it brick-paved streets for pedestrians. There are about 50 19th-century buildings which used to be   the Gooderham & Worts Distillery. Now there are still breweries, and lots of cafes, restaurants.

reviews.title: Bang for your Buck
text: We highly recommend this! My husband and I shopped around the distillery district first during the Winter Festival. Really beautiful and lots of nice shops. Our tour was with David and he was very knowledgeable and did an excellent job! Everything was very interesting, and we were taken to areas we wouldn't have went to had we not done the tour. David was so kind and fun. Highly highly recommend !!! Worth your buck.

reviews.title: So much to see!
text: 5 stars! We spent the day here shopping, eating, taking photos, and enjoying ourselves! This is a great place to hang out & eat yummy treats!

reviews.title: Nice
text: There is plenty of places here where you can just relax, seat in a nice sofa and enjoy of life music or a football game on a giant screen. The stores are not very cheap but there are lots of options to grab a quick snack.

reviews.title: Distillery Historic District - Toronto
text: The Distillery Historic District was fascinating. We took a short walk to St Lawrence Market which was fabulous (100+ food vendors - amazing!)

reviews.title: Good place to know
text: I’ve stayed there in the weekend and I loved it. You find a lot of stores, restaurants and good places to take a beer and wine.
The atmosphere is friendly. Everybody needs to know and enjoy the place.

reviews.title: Toronto’s Distillery District During Christmas
text: Visiting Toronto's Distillery District during the Christmas season is like stepping into a winter wonderland where history and modernity meld seamlessly. This charming area, with its cobblestone streets and Victorian-era architecture, offers an enchanting experience that captures the festive spirit perfectly.

The district is adorned with stunning Christmas decorations and twinkling lights that cast a magical glow over the historic buildings. Each turn reveals a new picture-perfect scene, from the iconic Gooderham & Worts sign to the towering Christmas tree that becomes a focal point for visitors. The festive atmosphere is palpable, making it an ideal spot for both photographers and casual strollers alike.

Beyond its visual appeal, the Distillery District is bustling with activity. The small eateries and quaint shops add to its charm, offering everything from artisanal foods to unique, handcrafted gifts. Whether you're looking for a cozy café to warm up in or a boutique to find the perfect holiday gift, there's something to delight everyone.

Even if shopping isn’t on your agenda, wandering through the district is a joy in itself. The blend of historic facades with contemporary installations and pop-up markets creates an immersive experience that’s rich in both culture and holiday cheer. Street performers and carolers add to the ambiance, filling the air with music and merriment.

An afternoon or evening spent here is highly recommended. It’s not just a place to visit but an experience to be savored, especially during the festive season. For anyone in Toronto during Christmas, the Distillery District is an absolute must-see, capturing the essence of holiday magic in a truly unique setting.

reviews.title: Nice area
text: This is a great area for couples or families. A perfect place to explore the various shops and restaurants/bars. It’s so easy to spend an afternoon or evening just wandering around.

reviews.title: My Favourite Area in Toronto
text: This is far and away my favourite area in Toronto and a must stop for any visitor.  It has great shops, daily free outdoor concerts and so much character.  There are so many amazing restaurants with beautiful patios and many things to do and see.

reviews.title: A must ...
text: A fantastic part of the town dedicated to fun .Lots of restaurants/bars ..unusual shops and even an outdoor stage which showcases live music on the weekend.
Great way to spend an afternoon..  My favourite eatery was Pure Spirit .. Well worth a visit ..

reviews.title: Great date venue
text: My husband & I visited on a rainy day which took away from the experience but I can picture couples going on dates there because it was very charming & the industrial setting so quaint. There was a New Orleans theme going on & it reminds me of the warehouse district there. At night, it must be a great place to go with the lights & lively atmosphere.

reviews.title: Wonderful place to visit
text: We loved wandering around the Distillery District. It has been beautifully converted and is full of historic information. There were loads of interesting shops, galleries and bars and it is a great place to while away a few hours.
